Isaac O. is 32 years old, married and the father of three children, aged between 3-6, with one attending school. Isaac has been in mixed farming for ten years. He sells maize, beans, bananas, tea and milk locally.

With this loan of 25,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo, Isaac will buy a dairy cow. The proceeds will help pay school fees and improve family living standards in terms of food and wealth. In five years, Isaac hopes to increase the dairy cows to five. Isaac's major challenges are the low market prices for milk and farm produce and the poor road network which interferes with daily transportation. He thanks Juhudi for the financing and hopes for more.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Tabrey

texts.en:
Tabrey B. is married to a polygamist.  They are blessed with six children, all are going to school.  The fact that she was unable to acquire a basic education because she did not go to school has made life very difficult for her .  She was unable to assist her husband to cater for the family. Worst of all is the fact that her children are unable to study freely because of the fees.  They are also unable to have three square meals a day. 

With this loan she plans to buy drugs, chemicals, and planting seeds. She knows her business is going to succeed because she had acquired some basic trainings in finance management and in how to choose a good business from GHAPE.  

She was motivated to become a member of GHAPE by her husband who became a GHAPE member in 2001. Since then she has successfully borrowed and repaid loans seven times. The profit from these loans helped her pay her children school fees and provide some basic needs like food for the family.
	

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase drugs, chemicals, and planting seeds

loans.name: Memena's Group

texts.en:
Memena is the coordinator of her group, called Dios Proveera 3, 5 (God will provide). She is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanding her business. She operates a clothing store and is planning to invest in it by buying different types of clothes, for men, women and kids. She will use any profits to reinvest in her business, Christmas time sales are really good, and that's why she wants to have plenty of merchandise. 

Memena's story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Dominican and Haitian clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the economy is dominated by the sugarcane harvest and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and their two children. She wants to be strong for work and help her children to have a good education.

The small picture in the lower right corner is the group coordinator, Memena.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Homero

texts.es:
Homero C. trabaja en un rancho cerca de la ciudad la mayor parte de la semana y su esposa en casa para el cuidado de la casa.
En este momento no cuenta con todo el capital para impermeabilizar su vivienda y mantenimiento de las paredes exteriores dañadas, este proyecto lo quiere arreglar antes de que empiece la  temporada de lluvia y se trasmine el agua y sea mayor el problema.
texts.en: Homero C. works on a farm near the city for the greater part of the week and his wife stays at home to take care of the housework. At this time he does not have the capital funds to weather-proof their house and to repair the damaged exterior walls. He wants to complete these projects before the rainy season in order to prevent the major problem of water from seeping through.

loans.use: To weather-proof their house and to repair the damaged exterior walls.

loans.name: Liberata

texts.en:
Liberata T. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 69 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Liberata owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste. Liberata has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Liberata joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 27,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be her 9th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Mrs. Sou S. was born in 1951. She is a villager who lives in Lvea Sa Kandal village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Chea Ry, are farmers who own a 1.50-hectare plot of land that they use to grow rice to sell to support the family. But they do not have enough farming supplies to grow rice. Therefore, Mrs. Sou S. would like a loan to purchase a water machine to use to grow rice. This couple has a child who is security guard in a private company. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine

loans.name: Monina

texts.en:
Monina C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 59 years old and married. To make a living, Monina owns & operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Monina also grows pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market.

Monina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.  Monina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is currently in the business of selling soft drinks. She is 40 years old. A widow, she has three children, all of whom go to school. Margret requested a loan to stock more soft drinks to sell. With the extra profits, she hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Benon

texts.en: Benon wants a loan to pay school fees for his daughter. He lives in Kyenjojo Uganda. He deals in diary farming and crop production. He dreams of educating his children and building a permanent house.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his daughter

loans.name: Abelina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN DEL CARMEN DE YUNCAYPATA”; El banco está ubicado en la comunidad de Yuncaypata, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Abelina; la socia tiene 59 años de edad casada y tiene 5 hijos; la socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de crianza de animales menores como cuyes, gallinas y chanchos, la socia lleva años realizando este negocio ella cría a estos animalitos para luego venderlos a sus clientes especialmente a los restaurantes que son los que más piden pero también tiene otros clientes que le solicitan, la socia es una persona bien alegre y con muchas ganas de salir adelante por su familia.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de alimento de sus animalitos como pasto, purina, maiz entre otros.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota
texts.en:
Here is a member of the communal bank named "Virgen del Carmen de Yuncaypata". It is located in the community of Yuncaypata, in the province of Cusco and the department of Cusco.

Her name is Abelina. She is 59 years old, married, and she has 5 children. She alternates her daily activities with her livestock business. She raises small animals such as guinea pigs, chickens, and pigs. She has many years in the business and she raises these livestock for later resale to clients, especially to restaurants that offer the most demand, but she also sells to other clients who make requests. She is a very happy person and she is very eager to keep working for the sake of her family.

She requests a loan to purchase feed for her little animals, such as hay, kibble, corn and others. 

She is happy for her loan and she is committed to making her payments.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her livestock such as hay

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a married woman; she has two children who attend school. Her husband is a businessman and he contributes to the support of his family. They live in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent, and school fees. 

She has operated a retail shop for the past three years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Salome sells household items, like maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, rice, and cooking fats. She faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her area of operation. She dreams of owning a retail shop in the future. 

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) she is requesting she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, and soft drinks for sale. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and soft drinks

loans.name: Haidi

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAN ISIDRO DE YANAHURA 5TO PARADERO”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Haidi; ella tiene 22 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 1 hijo; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de tienda de accesorios de celulares, ella trabaja juntamente con su esposo y venden cargadores, cables y celulares en el distrito de Urubamba, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de accesorios para celulares. La socia solicita el préstamo para accesorios para celulares al por mayor.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Haidi is a member of the "San Isidro de Yanahura 5to Paradero" community bank which is located in Urubamba district, in Urubamba province, in Cusco department.

Haidi is 22 years old, lives with her partner, and has one child.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her business which is a store selling cell phone accessories.  She works together with her husband and they sell chargers, cables and cell phones in Urubamba district.  Through this business, Haidi gets her children ahead in life.  She would like to expand her business selling cell phone accessories and is requesting this loan to buy cell phone accessories wholesale.

Haidi is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy cell phone accessories wholesale

loans.name: Flora

texts.es:
La Sra. Flora es originaria del municipio de El Sauce, es madre de cuatro hijos de los cuales solamente uno tiene a su cargo, cuenta con su propio negocio el cual consiste en la venta de granos como arroz, frijoles, maíz, sorgo y verduras ubicada en la Terminal de buses de dicho municipio contando con mucho años de experiencia y trabajando en conjunto con su esposo.
Desde que inició su negocio se ha caracterizado por dar una buena atención a sus clientes y gracias al esfuerzo propio ha podido diversificarlo en productos y a bajos precios lo que atrae la atención de los mismos, también le ha permitido sacar adelante a su familia y adquirir su propia vivienda. Una de las necesidades que tiene esta señora es contar con más capital para adquirir más granos y verduras para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes, por tal razón decidió solicitar su séptimo crédito en Ceprodel con el objetivo de satisfacer dicha demanda.
texts.en:
Flora is originally from the municipality of El Sauce. She is the mother of four children, of whom only two live with her. She has her own business, which consists of selling grains such as rice, beans, corn, sorghum and also vegetables. Her business is located at the bus terminal in El Sauce. She has had many years of experience and works together with her husband. 

Since she began her business, she has always provided good service to her customers. Thanks to her own hard work, she has been able to diversify her products and sell them at low prices, which attracted the attention of her customers. This has allowed her to help her family get ahead and to buy her own house. 

One of the things she needs is to have more capital to buy more grains and vegetables, to satisfy customer demand. This is why she decided to request her seventh loan from Ceprodel, with the goal of meeting said demand.

loans.use: to buy sorghum, corn, beans, rice, and vegetables.

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi Karibai is a 44 year old married man with eight children to his name. He is a fisherman in Marereni town in Malindi and has been in this business for the past ten years now. He earns a monthly income of about KES 10,000, which he uses to take care of his family. 


This is Hamisi’s first loan cycle with KADET LTD, and he has requested a loan of KES 10,000. He intends to use the entire loan to purchase new and bigger fishing nets and diving glasses for his business.  He intends to use the anticipated profits to continue looking after his family and continue educating his children who are still in school. In the future, he hopes to have enough savings to allow him to purchase land where he would be able to practice commercial farming.

loans.use: to purchase new and bigger fishing nets and diving glasses for his business

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie is 36 years old. She has five children who are aged 6-15 years. Her husband is a farmer and they are happily married. Pelagie sells foodstuffs such as sorghum and some animals. She has done this business for 10 years. 

This business has enabled her to feed her family and develop her standard of living. She is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum and make more profits. With the profit she plans to pay school fees for her children

loans.use: to buy sorghum for sale.

loans.name: Mujeres Loma Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Loma se ha formado gracias al entusiasmo de las vecinas y amigas de la ciudad de Caacupé, ellas oyeron hablar del programa de mujeres emprendedoras y se propusieron formar un comité. Actualmente cuenta con 15 miembros, todas las miembros trabajan arduamente para poder ayudarse las unas a las otras.
La Sra. Cyntia, se dedica a la elaboración y posterior venta de panificados. Ella, con la ayuda de su marido todos los días preparan panes frescos para ofrecerles a sus clientes. Trabajan todos los días, sin excepción de domingos ni feriados.
Ella solicita el credito para la compra de harinas, huevos, levaduras y demás especias que podría necesitar para la elaboración de sus panificados. Ella manifiesta que esta muy esperanzada en el credito, puesto que le sera de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
The committee named “Mujeres Loma” was started as a result of some enthusiastic friends and neighbors from the city of Caacupé. They heard about the Program of Women Entrepreneurs and proposed to form a committee. There are currently 15 members. All of them work hard so that they can help one another.

Sra. Cyntia prepares and sells baked goods. She and her husband prepare fresh bread each day to offer to their customers. They work every day, with the exception of Sundays and holidays.

She is requesting a loan to buy flour, eggs, yeast, and certain spices that she needs for preparing her baked goods. Cyntia says that she is very hopeful that this loan will be of great help.

loans.use: to purchase flour, eggs, yeast, and spices.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 32-year-old married man with three children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family is vested in him and his desire is to build them a permanent house.

He sells cereals and rides a motorcycle for living. The major challenges faced are the high cost of farming, since he carries out his farming on a hired piece of land, and the mechanical breakdown of his motorcycle. He dreams of owning five motorcycles and a piece of land. Hassan intends to use the credit facility to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Hay

texts.en: Hay is a farmer. Her husband is a pig seller. Their income is $6 per day. There is one child staying with this family, he is a worker earning $5 per day. Every month, Hay spends $30 on food, $10 on electricity, $10 on house rent, $10 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a motorbike for her son to travel to work. In the future, she expects to buy some more pigs for her husband to feed and sell. She hopes her husband's career will continue running well and will extend to be a farm to make more income.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her son traveling to work.

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Âgé de 42 ans et né à Safebougou, Monsieur  Adama est marié à une épouse et est père de 7 enfants. Il habite dans le quartier Médina coura de la préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso) avec sa famille. 
Du à des problèmes sociaux il n’a pas pu continuer les études primaires et s’est très vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus depuis son enfance auprès de son père. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il finit par opter pour  la vente de poissons fumés  il y’a 14 ans. Les poissons fumés sont  très prisés à Koutiala.  
Afin d’augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il décida de  rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a bientôt une année. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel  et le précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Monsieur Adama compte acheter, 5 paniers de poissons fumés à Korientzé (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs d’ethnie  Bozo  et  Somonô avec ce financement et effectue sa vente au  marché de poissons de Koutiala  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’ hommes  au comptant, en détail et à crédit. 
Adama compte  réaliser un bénéfice de 120.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera  pour  le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire ses besoins  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama was born in Safebougou. He is 42 years old, married, and the father of seven children. He lives with his family in the district of Medina Coura, prefecture of Koutiala (in the Sikasso region).

Social issues having prevented him from pursuing his primary studies, he quickly became interested in income-generating activities as a child alongside his father. After attempting several activities without success, he started selling smoked fish 14 years ago. Smoked fish are in high demand in Koutiala.

In order to bolster his working capital and strengthen his selling power, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso nearly a year ago. This is his second individual loan with the MFI; the first one was repaid without incident. 

With this loan, Mr. Adama plans to buy five baskets of smoked fish in Korientzé (in the Mopti region) from fishermen of Bozo and Somonô ethnic backgrounds. He conducts his sales at retail at the fish market of Koutiala for cash or credit. His clientele consists of both men and women.

Mr. Adama expects to earn 120,000 FCFA per month, which he will use to repay the loan to Soro Yiriwaso and pay for family expenses. Any remainder will be reinvested in his activity.

loans.use: to buy smoked fish for resale

loans.name: Mata De Palma 3 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Carmen is one of the members from the group Mata D. Palma 3 & 5, (Palm tree) named like this because this is the community where the group is located in Hato Mayor city, in the eastern part of the country. Hato Mayor is a fairly mountainous region where the principal industry is agriculture. 

Carmen is a mother of four children and they live together with her and their father. She said that her most difficult challenge has been to have her business at all. In the past it was very difficult, because she did not have enough money to start one up, but after she found Esperanza and took out her loans, she was able (like other members in this group) to open her business.  

Carmen is excited about her 12th loan with Esperanza. After almost six years with her business, she has expanded her little butcher shop into a bigger one, with more quantity of meats to supply more clients. With this loan she will increase her inventory and make even bigger sales. She will use the profits to invest in her butcher shop. She is planning to make some changes in the structure. 

She dreams of having a nice house and a successful business with employees. Carmen and her group thank all of you for your support.

loans.use: to buy different sorts of meat (pork, beef, chicken).

loans.name: Edith Damaris

texts.es:
En el Municipio de santa Rosa del Peñón, departamento de León, la Señora Edith Damaris a diario se levanta desde muy temprano para iniciar sus labores de trabajo con la fianlidad de llevar a su humilde casa el sustento para toda la familia. 

Actualmente ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito para ampliar y mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda, para ello está solicitando el crédito para la compra de materiales de construcción, tales como arena, cementó y zinc ya que con empezará la construcción de un anexo a su vivienda (Cocina), para las mejores condiciones de su familia.
texts.en:
In the town of Santa Rosa del Peñón, Mrs. Edith Damaris gets up very early every day to work with the goal of brining sustenance to her family in their humble home.

She came by Ceprodel to request a loan to enlarge and improve her home.  This is the reason she’s asking for the loan: to buy building materials and supplies like: sand, cement and metal sheeting  to start adding on to her home (kitchen) to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and metal sheeting.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a hardworking 33 year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with two children who are still in school. For the last four years, he has been operating a cafeteria to earn a living. He has worked hard to grow his business. 

He is requesting for a loan of 25,000 Kenya shillings to buy seats.

loans.use: To buy seats

loans.name: Wiedee

texts.en:
Wiedee is 39 years old and lives in community by the airport.  She is married and her husband works at Firestone.  They have five children between the ages of 17 and 22 years old.  For the past four years she has operated a local restaurant in her community.  She learned this business from her sister.

Wiedee requests a loan to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, coal, and onion for her restaurant.  She plans to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice, pepper, coal, and onion for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Noonkokua

texts.en:
Noonkokua is a 36-year-old married lady. She has three children who depend on her. She has been a farmer in Narok, Kenya for a period of six years with an income of about KES 6,000 per month.

Noonkokua learned about KADET LTD through other women registered in her area of residence. She accessed a previous loan, which she repaid successfully without any complications. This is her second loan from KADET LTD and she wants to use the loan to buy farm supplies such as seedlings and fertilizers. 

She hopes to grow different crops on her farm and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like fertilizer

loans.name: Lilia

texts.es: La sra. Lilia de 59 años es una mujer emprendedora; hace 15 años afuera de su domicilio puso una pequeña mesa con dulces, frituras, galletas, panes y helados para vender a ella siempre le ha gustado el trato con la gente y gracias a su amabilidad al poco tiendo la mesita en la que ella vendió se convirtió en una tienda de abarrotes grande en la que ella vende, productos enlatados, refrescos, frutas, verduras, lácteos, botanas, galletas, dulces y un poco de papelería como lo son lápices, cuadernos, borradores, sacapuntas pegamentos y mas.  Para la Sra. Lilia su mayor logro en la vida es no depender económicamente de sus hijos ya que ella sabe que ellos han formado una familia es esa quien tienen la obligación de velar día con día, es por ello que solicita el apoyo para compra de mercancía y así poder surtir mas su negocio y que este le siga dejando ganancias para sus necesidades básicas y al mismo tiempo para ir surtiendo mas su negocio.
texts.en:
Lilia, 59, is an enterprising woman.  Fifteen years ago she set up a small table outside her house with candy, fried fast food, cookies, bread and ice-cream to sell.  She’s always enjoyed dealing with people and thanks to her kindness the little table she used for sales gradually became a large grocery store where she sells canned goods, soft-drinks, fruit, vegetables, snacks, cookies, candy and some stationery supplies like pencils, notebooks, erasers, pencil sharpeners, glue and more. 

For Lilia, her greatest accomplishment has been not having to depend economically on her children since she knows that they have formed their own families and that’s where they should focus their efforts towards their wellbeing every day.  

This is why she’s asking for support to purchase merchandise to better stock her store so that it will continue to produce profits for her to meet her basic needs while at the same time continue to increase her store’s stock.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Namboani A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Namboani A Group in Western Kenya! Francis is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Francis takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to educate his children, access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Francis had a very good maize yield harvesting 22 bags on 2 1/2 acres of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Francis was only able to harvest seven bags of maize on 2 1/2 acres of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Francis and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Francis will educate his children and ensure food security.

In 2012, the members of Namboani A group will each plant between ½ and 3 acres of maize.

He is pictured with his group members in the photograph above.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Fanny

texts.es: La Sra. Fanny vive la zona del abasto en una casa en anticrético, es madre soltera tiene 45 años, tiene dos hijas las cuales le ayudan venden con ella y también estudian. La Sra. Fanny se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva (pantalones jeans para hombres y mujeres, conjunto para niñas y niños, poleras y blusas ropas que las compra  en la feria son productos panameños) las cuales vende a crédito y también ambulan  por los mercados vendiendo sus  mercaderías. Es el segundo crédito que se le da en su anterior crédito  a demostrado ser cliente responsable, el crédito que esta solicitando es para aumentar su capital de trabajo, compra de mercadería (ropas, chinelas y carteras) y el resto del dinero es para el nuevo negocio que esta implantando, en el mercado abasto la venta de papas por bolsada  y cebollas por bolsada, un negocio por el cual ella esta viendo buenas ganancias. La Sra. Fanny es clienta que esta siempre pendiente de cualquier tipo de negocio, mujer preparada y con ganas de superación.
texts.en: Sra. Fanny, 45, lives in an anticretico in Abasto.  [An "anticretico" is a kind of lease-purchase tenancy arrangement common in Bolivia.] She is a single mother with two daughters who help her with her business when they're not in school.  Fanny sells new clothing (jeans for men, women and children; sweaters; and blouses), all made in Panama, that she buys from a local wholesale market.  She works as a street vendor and sells on credit.  This is her second loan and she proved before that she is a responsible borrower.  She will use part of the loan to buy merchandise (clothing, footwear, purses) for her business and the rest for a new business selling bulk supplies of potatoes and onions in the market at Abasto. She is confident that she will earn a good income from the new business.  Sra. Fanny is determined to make a success of whatever she does because she's driven and hard working.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her retail businesses.

loans.name: Ozoda

texts.ru: Озода занимается подшивкой скатерти и вязанием шерстяных шапок. Ей 49 лет. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 20 лет. Она вдова. У нее двое детей. Ее вид деятельности является семейным. Она берет кредит для приобретения ниток и тканей.
texts.en: Ozoda works in knitting tablecloths and wool caps. She is 49 years old. She has been in this line of work for 20 years. She is a widow and has two children. Her work is a family business. She is requesting a loan to purchase yarn and fabric.

loans.use: purchase yarn and fabric.

loans.name: Leaiti

texts.en:
Leaiti is a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Fogapoa. She is married and has six school-aged children. Leaiti makes her living by owning and operating a fishing business. Her main source of income comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Leaiti has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1000 WST per month from these activities.

In 2011, Leaiti joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan from SPBD, in the amount of 1000 WST, to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Leaiti plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment.

loans.name: Sinan

texts.en:
Sinan, 33, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a garment worker. Her husband is a carpenter. Sinan is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future, she would like to purchase rice to store in a warehouse in order to resell it when the price is higher. She would also like to build a fence around the house.

Sinan is not in the picture; the man in the picture is her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Seoub

texts.en:
Seoub, 39, is married and resides in Kampong Chnang Province. She is employed at a garment factory and her husband is in the army. 

Seoub is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase rice from local farmers to resell when it is profitable. In the future, Seoub would like to use additional income to purchase more rice stock. 

This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy rice to resell.

loans.name: Camela

texts.en:
Camela is a widow and has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. She works hard to support her family.
Camela has requested a loan of 21,000 PHP through Kiva partner NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.
Camela has been in this business for seven years. She would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Joucelyn

texts.en: Artisan Joucelyn specializes in traditional Peruvian embroideries on handbags and belts. She would like to invest in the purchase of wool yarn, leather and hand-woven fabrics for her handcrafted accessories. She has been selling through NOVICA since 2010. This is her story: "In 2008, I began to design and work hand-in-hand with skilled artisans. I absolutely love being a part of this work, which provides a living for many artisan families and, at the same time, shows the whole world Peru's rich and diverse textile arts from my country's coast and sierra. It's so fulfilling to discover and learn about these traditional arts that have been handed down from generation to generation." "With this micro-credit I'll be able to stock up on my prime materials to prepare enough products to meet the demands of my sales. Thank you very much for your help with this micro-credit." Use the link below to view Joucelyn's embroidered handbags and belts on the NOVICA site: http://www.novica.com/kiva/7280

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of wool yarn, leather and hand-woven fabrics for her handcrafted accessories.

loans.name: 1Dushyigikirane Group

texts.en:
Albertine is the group leader, aged 30. She is married with three children aged between 1 and 7 years; two of them go to school.

The group is called Dushyigikirane, which means “Support Each Other” in English. They sell different products, and they wish to expand their businesses for changing their better future.

Albertine has a shop and has been in a business for eight years. With the loan, she would like to buy more soaps and salt to resell. The profits from the business will be used to expand her business and buy food for home consumption.

loans.use: to buy more soaps and salt to resell.

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en: Zawadi is a married woman. She has 3 children. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, bread, flour and other items. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be low stock. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, flour, soap and other items. Her business goal is to have a big business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to university level. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to puchase additional stock

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, flour, soap and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase the stock

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Mr. K. does double duty as a businessman and an elder at a local church. A teacher by profession, he is married with 5 children. He started as a clothing vendor and slowly developed his business to the wholesale level. He now buys in bulk and sells to small-scale vendors. He plans to use the loan from PEMCI to expand the shoe sale side of the business. He is a respected and active member of the local community through his church and also in his personal capacity. He has mentored a number of young people in his church who are actively engaged in similar businesses. We believe that supporting him will have an indirect impact on the local community through his interactions.

loans.use: Stock his clothing & shoe business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with four children, three in primary and one in nursery school. She is a secretary by profession.

She started her business in 1996, with capital from her monthly savings, to supplement her salary. Her business includes buying fresh fruits from local farmers and selling them in the nearest town at a higher price. With the help of a loan from PEMCI, she plans to open a store and increase her stock. With the income generated, she is able to contribute to the wellbeing of her family and community.

loans.use: To promote fruit selling

loans.name: Manseray

texts.en: Forty five years old, Manseray lives on the outskirts of Makeni town in Sierra Leone with her four children and husband.  While her husband is employed as a driver, his earnings do not cover the family expenses.  Four years after the civil war in the country, Manseray started her small soap-making business with capital of only $10. Later, she joined SMT and obtained a small loan for expanding.  On a small scale, Manseray diversified her business to the selling of fire wood.  She will use the requested loan funds to expand both her soap-making and firewood selling businesses.  She is planning to build a small shelter/store for the firewood business.

loans.use: Building a small shelter to house firewood stock

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mrs. Mina S., 28 years old, lives in Thecho, Lalitpur, Nepal.  She is an active member in her group.  She lives in a joint family household with her father-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law and her husband.

Her husband, Shankar S., is a bicycle mechanic and opened his bicycle workshop 9 years ago.  He does not have enough money to buy materials such as tires, wheels, screws, and other materials for his shop, so she is seeking a loan of $150 to invest in her husband's bicycle workshop. 

All members of her family are totally depended on the shop.  She wants to invest more to earn more to maintain her family and for her own improvement.

loans.use: To buy bicycle repair goods

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en: Esmeralda is a 29-year-old single mother.  She has three children that are studying in the public school of the small town.  She prepares and sells fried chicken pieces, fried bananas, and empanadas.  She plans to invest the loan requested to purchase raw materials like flour, spices and so on, to keep producing her fried foods.  She also plans to buy more bananas and chicken than before and thus increase her earnings.  That way, Esmeralda will be better able to cope with her children's needs.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like bananas, flour, spices and chicken in order to prepare fried foods for sale

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo belongs to the Las Almendras ("The Almonds") community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali. She is 42 years old and a single mother with 1 son. To support herself and her son, she decided to use her first loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100) to set up a small food stand selling local dishes. She now makes her living from the business selling regional foods (juanes and tacachos, dishes popular in Peru's Amazon region), tending the stand along with her son. They get up very early to make the juanes before Consuelo takes her son to school.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (1,000 Peruvian soles or about US$336), to be repaid in 5 months, Consuelo will buy a table, 5 kilograms of rice, 3 chickens, 2 bunches of bananas and a litre of cooking oil.

Consuelo is very happy to have a healthy child who she can send to school and especially satisfied that she can do so even though she is the family's sole breadwinner.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Consuelo pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, del Jr. Manco Capac 323 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 1 hijo, es madre soltera, es así que Consuelo, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto para la venta de comida Regional. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño puesto donde vende comida regional ( Juanes y tacacho), la misma que atiende junto a su hijo, se levantan muy temprano para preparar los juanes y luego lleva a la escuela a su hijo.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000 (US$ 336.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará una mesa, 5 kilos de arroz, 3 gallinas, 2 racimos de plátano y 1 litro de aceite.

Consuelo está muy contenta de tener a su hijo sano y en la escuela, y satisfecha con ello dado que ella sola puede costear las necesidades de su casa.

loans.use: Buy supplies for restaurant business.

loans.name: Maribel Del Carmen

texts.es:
The business of selling all kinds of clothing is a hard one to maintain because of the high levels of competition in that market. However, mindful of this fact, Mrs. Maribel del Carmen R. has had this business for 7 years, having started with a capital of $5,000.00 from her personal savings.

She started as a street vendor, offering her wares throughout the city, with the clothes in her arms. Later on she established herself in the market of the Terminal, where she has a fixed stand out in the open, in an area where there is a lot of competition. Before having this business, she used to sell tortillas, and with her profit from their sale she was able to save enough money to switch businesses. Switching to clothing sales allowed her to improve financially and have a better quality of life for her and her family of two children.

All the progress made by this courageous woman is thanks to Ceprodel which has offered her financial support for a year and a half now, having authorized a total of 7 loans which have helped her to increase her business, stocking better quality of clothing. In this way, Mrs. Carmen makes a living with dignity, and supports her two children who are more precious to her than anything else in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio de venta de ropa para de todo tipo es un negocio muy difícil de mantener por el hecho de que hoy en día la competencia se arrecia y cada vez existen nuevos competidores en este mercado. Sin embargo, consiente de esto, la señora Maribel del Carmen Rodríguez tiene 7 años de tener el negocio que lo inició con un monto de C$5.000.00 producto de ahorros que ella tenia.

Inicia como vendedora ambulante viajando por toda la ciudad y la ropa en los brazos, para luego establecerse en el mercado la Terminal en donde tiene un puesto fijo al aire libre, que es un área en donde hay mucha competencia. Antes de tener este negocio vendía tortillas y con el fondo que logró ahorrar cambió de negocio pudiendo superarse económicamente teniendo ahora un mejor nivel de vida para ella y su familia que son dos hijos

Todo este progreso de esta valiente dama se debe gracias a Ceprodel ya que le ha brindado apoyo financiero de hace año y medio atrás habiendo obtenido un total de 7 créditos que le han ayudado en el crecimiento de su negocio el cual lo ha surtido con mejores marcas de ropa y en mejores condiciones de calidad. De esta manera digna se gana la vida la señora Carmen y así mantiene a sus dos hijos que son lo más preciado que ella tiene en la vida.

loans.use: Buying merchandise (Compra de mercadería)

loans.name: Nasiah

texts.en: Nasiah, 28, is the mother of 2 children who sells soap at her house, earning $3 a day. Her husband, A., is giving people rides on his motorcycle taxi and earning $3 a day. She is asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business captial, and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add her business capital

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.es:
Mrs. Jesusa Q. lives in her own home in the Tupac Amaru zone of the city of La Paz with her husband, Mr. Jhony Morales and their four children. Mrs. Q. sells peanuts retail. Her husband transports meat from the municipal slaughterhouse to the various butcher shops in the neighborhood.

The requested loan will be used to construct a reinforced cement slab (cement and iron) and close frontal wall of the home.

This is the seventh time that Jesusa has requested a loan from Impro. The socioeconomic analysis carried out by Impro was favorable and has qualified Jesusa for the loan. She has been an Impro client since 2001.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Jesusa Q. vive en casa propia en la zona de Tupac Amaru de la Ciudad de La Paz con su esposo, el señor Jhony Morales y sus cuatro hijos. La señora Jesusa Q. realiza la comercialización de maní al por menor. Y su esposo transporta carne del matadero municipal a las distintas carnicerías de barrio.

El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción de una losa de hormigón armado (cemento y fierro) y el cerramiento del muro frontal.

Esta es la séptima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un crédito. Es cliente de nuestra institución desde el año 2001.

loans.use: Construction of a cement slab reinforced by iron and construction of the frontal wall of  her home.

loans.name: Murodalli

texts.ru:
Murodalli S. lives in the region Rudaki in the village Teppai Samarkandi. He is 42 years old, he is married, and has 4 children. He has a Bachelor's Degree in Education. He works as a teacher in middle school № 45 in Rudaki. Apart from working as a teacher, Murodalli earns additional income through food sales. He imports inventory from Dushanbe and resells it in his own store. This business helps him to provide his family with the needed money. Moreover, his business helps local residents who can purchase the needed goods at his store without leaving the village and spending addition time.

Murodalli is asking for loan so he could purchase a fridge to store perishable foods. The new fridge will help him store his inventory, increase the assortment of his goods, and the local residents to purchase fresh products. He plans to pay off the loan within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Шоев Муродалли проживает в районе Рудаки в поселке Теппаи Самарканди. Ему 42 года , женат и имеет 4 детей. Образование высшее. По профессии учитель средней школы. Работает в школе № 45 района Рудаки. Кроме работы в школе , Муродалли зарабатывает на жизнь путем торговли продуктами питания . Имеет небольшой магазинчик рядом с домом. Привозит товар из города Душанбе , покупая у оптовых продавцов и продает у себя в магазине. Этот бизнес помогает обеспечить семью необходимым доходом. Кроме того товар продаваемый им в его магазине, товары первой необходимости помогают населению покупают продукты, не выезжая из района, не тратя на дорогу денег и не тратя время.Но клиент хочет купить холодильную камеру для хранения продуктов , которые быстро портятся . Для этого Муродалли хочет получить кредит , что поможет ему выполнить запланированное. Это поможет хранить продукты питания , увеличить ассортимент товаров , а так же поможет населению покупать свежие продукты. Погасит кредит клиент в течении 9 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Ashibae

texts.en:
Ashibae is a single woman with two children, ages 8 and 2 years. Ashibae is a soap seller, a business she started in 2007. She works from 10am to 2pm each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She hopes for a loan to buy more soap for her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a collection of bedspreads and tablecloths for her business.

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr:
In her fifties, Mrs. Marie A. has sold condiments for 15 years or more in Agongbomey along side the paved road that runs opposite the middle school CPDM (Complexe Polytechnique Dally Maccagnon). She usually makes her purchases in the market Dantokpa, the largest market in the economic capital of Benin. She shops for stock that will satisfy customer demand most of whom live within her neighborhood. Originally from Oueme, she is married and the mother of four, two of which are still dependent on her. This is the fifth loan she has requested. This loan will help her to strengthen her capital.

Translated from French to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

La cinquantaine, dame A. Marie vendait depuis une quinzaine d'années des condiments à Agongbomey au bord de la voie pavée opposée au collège CPDM (Complexe Polytechnique Dally Maccagnon). Généralement, elle fait ses achats au marché DANTOKPA, le plus grand marché de la capitale économique du BENIN afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui est essentiellement constituée des habitants de son quartier. Originaire du département de l’OUEME, elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants dont deux sont encore à sa charge. Elle est à sa cinquième demande de prêt. Ce prêt l’aidera à renforcer son capital.

loans.use: To purchase one 25 liter drum of vegetable oil and 2 baskets of tomatoes and 3 baskets of onions.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
This lady dedicates herself to the distribution of all types of items (blankets, gifts, etc.), allowing payment to be made on credit or in installments. She has been a widow for twelve years, single-handedly supporting five children who are now grown and live on their own. The oldest is in sales and lives in Santa Cruz, while three others live in Cochabamba. The youngest works with her and lives in La Paz. Viki, as she is known, rents out a room and the kitchen in her house. She lives alone, and always looks out for her seven grandchildren. The loan would help greatly, given that it would allow her to buy a vehicle better distribute her merchandise. Having an improved means of transportation would also economize her time so she can devote more of herself to her grandchildren.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora se dedica a la distribución de todo (frazadas, regalos y otros) los da a crédito o sea para que paguen a cuotas, es viuda hace 12 años, sola saco adelante a 5 hijos todos ya mayores edad e independientes, la mayor se dedica al comercio y radica en Santa Cruz, tres de ellos viven en Cochabamba y la menor que trabaja con ella radica en La Paz, Viki como la conocen arrienda un cuarto y su cocina vive sola y siempre esta pendiente de sus nietos que son siete. El crédito le ayudara mucho ya que podra comprar un vehiculo para que pueda distribuir mejor su mercadería y así economizar su tiempo y así podrá dedicarse a sus nietos.

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of a vehicle to help her business.

loans.name: Rocio

texts.es:
Rocio is a single mother and has 5 children. She used to live with her partner but since they separated she has looked after all her family's expenses.She started her business a year ago, as she needed to make money to support her family. It was then she decided to make food like tamales and pays in her home, and began to sell them. Little by little she gained clients through word of mouth, and now her business allows her to give her children all they need.

She needs a loan of US$300, which she will repay in 6 months, in order to buy an oven that will allow her to do her work more quickly. With your help Rocio will be able to increase her business.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne, Kiva volunteer.

Rocio es madre soltera tiene cinco hijos, anteriormente vivía en unión libre pero se separo entonces ella se encarga de todos los gastos familiares. Inicio el negocio hace un año, ya que necesitaba tener dinero para mantener a su familia, fue entonces que deicidio hacer comida como tamales y pays en su casa y los empezó a vender, poco a poco se fue haciendo de clientes que la fueron recomendando y ahora este negocio le permite darle lo necesario a sus hijos.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $300 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar un horno que le permita hacer mas ágil su trabajo. Con tu ayuda Rocio hará crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase an oven

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 41-year-old Edith M. from Mwanza She is married with four children between the ages of 16 to 24. Edith has been selling children's clothing since 2003.  She works at the business for eight hours per day, six days per week. Edith currently earns about US$200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$350 to buy more clothing. In the future, she plans to increase her inventory. Edith thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok H. lives with her husband and their four children, three of whom are students, in Kampong Cham.  She works as a vendor selling vegetables in her village's market and earns about $7 each day, while her husband drives a taxi between Kampong Cham and Phnom Penh and earns about $10 each day.  In order to increase her profits from vending vegetables, Sok is requesting a loan of $400, which will be used to purchase vegetables in bulk for resale at retail prices.

Sok H. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband is pictured above.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Moyoplouki

texts.fr:
Madame P. Moyoplouki est née en 1974 à Landjakadja dans la préfecture de la Koza au nord du Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Elle a pour activité, la vente de céréale dans le quartier d’Agoè au nord de la ville de Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 1994 et est bien expérimenté.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de d’acheter 6 sacs de sorgho et 7 sacs de haricot.
texts.en:
Mrs. Moyoplouki P. was born in 1974 in Landjakadja, in the prefecture of Koza, in northern Togo. She is married, and the mother of four children who are all attending school. Her business is the sale of grains in the Agoe neighborhood, in the north of the city of Lomé. She started this activity in 1994, and she is indeed experienced. This first loan that she is requesting will permit her to buy 6 sacks of sorghum and 7 sacks of beans.

Translated from French by Abby Gray, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: To buy grains

loans.name: Ky

texts.en:
Mrs. Ky N., 52, and her husband, Mr. Nov Huo, 48, who live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1983 and have six children, two sons and four daughters. Four of her children are married and live outside the family house; one child is a garment factory worker and the other one attends school.

Ky has been selling vegetables in her village for fifteen years. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for twenty years. Ky is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase a motorbike for her child to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her child to drive to work

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Quế  năm nay 51 tuổi, chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1996. Gia đình chị có 4 con đều đã trưởng thành. Hiện tại  công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị Thái là từ buôn bán rau và thực phẩm với thu nhập  5.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị Quế mong muốn được vay thêm 20.000.000 đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Q. is 51 years old. She has joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 1996. She has 4 grown-up children. Currently her main source of monthly income of 5,000,000 VND (equivalent to $288/month) comes from selling vegetable and food. This time Mrs. Q. would like to borrow 20,000,000 VND (equivalent to $1150) to invest more in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Abdulvahob

texts.en:
Abdulvahob is 33 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children. He has been a farmer for the past 5 years, with the goal of supporting his household and satisfying the needs of his children. For Abdulvahob, agriculture is an activity that he likes to do. Vegetable production is what he enjoys the most as it is easier to cultivate these plants, and the produce, when harvested annually, is profitable. The earnings are greater when buyers purchase the production in large quantities reducing the expense of transporting the produce. There is also saving in transportation when buyers come to harvest and take the produce away themselves. 

This is Abdulvahob second loan with IMON International, and to date he has had no problems with his payments and all have been punctual. Abdulvahob wishes to invest the money in seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasee of the seeds and mineral fertilizer for growing seasonal vegetables

loans.name: Felipe

texts.es:
El señor Felipe J. tiene ya más de 2 años con su negocio de venta de abarrotes esté es el ingreso de su familiar. Con un crédito anterior de FVP el cual pago puntual mente pudo invertirle a su negocio. 
 Sin embargo a su negocio le falta más variedad de mercancía y además desea iniciar la venta de  verduras, lácteos, carne y productos congelados, y así obtener ingresos adicionales para su hijos que actual mente están estudiando.
texts.en:
Felipe J. has owned a grocery store for more than two years. This is his family's source of income. With a prior loan from FVP, which he repaid on time, he invested in his business. However his store still needs a greater variety of merchandise and he also wants to start selling vegetables, dairy products, meat, and frozen food items, thus earning additional income to support his children, who are currently in school.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock merchandise

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is the woman pictured sitting on the right, wearing the red khanga. Jamila has worked as a charcoal and "bites" seller in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma for the past 10 years. She belongs to the Kondoa Group Loan (Group code 2026). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business. She is hopping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business. This will allow her to get more food for her family and to start to save money for future use.

Jamila is married. She has one child, who is 17 years old.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal, wheat flour and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Luly Estela

texts.es:
La señora Luly Estela Z. G. tiene 25 años, vive en el caserío de Sicsa, distrito de Salpo, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudio hasta 4to de secundaria, dejo de estudiar debido a que sus madre falleció y su padre no la pudo apoyar con sus estudios. Tiene 01 hijo que depende económicamente de ella..
Luly se dedica a la compra-venta de animales hace 5 años, al inicio solo vendía huachos con las ganancias fue comprando otros animales para la venta, así también en tiempos de cosecha se dedica la compra-venta de cereales y papa, su negocio lo desarrolla en su domicilio.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su banco comunal “Luchando por el Progreso”, lo invirtió en la compra de un huacho.
Con el crédito de 1500 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra de una vaca.
Luly sueña con comprar su casa en Trujillo y tener una tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Luly Estela Z. G. is 25 years old and lives in Sicsa, Salpo district, in La Libertad, Perú. She completed her education to the 4th year of secondary school, but couldn’t finish her education because her mother passed away and her father didn’t have the financial means to continue to support her studies. She decided to help her mother with the household chores. She has 1 child who depends on her economically. Luly has dedicated herself to buying and selling of animals for 5 years. She started selling only huachos (a farm animal) and, with her earnings, was able to begin selling other types of animals. Also, in harvest season, she sells and buys grains and potatoes. She carries out her business from her home. With the first loan of 300.00 soles that she received from the “Luchando por el Progreso” (“Fighting for Progress”) cooperative bank, she invested in the purchase of a huacho. With the loan of 1500.00 soles, to be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of a cow. Luly has dreams of buying her home in Trujillo and of having a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Roxanne

texts.en: Roxanne buys and sells firewood in Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City, where she lives.  Married with two children, she started her business by using her own capital, but as demand grew, Roxanne approached HSPFI and was granted a loan of PHP 7,000.00. Her husband helps her in delivering the ordered firewood to their neighbors and neighboring villages. Roxanne believes that if she could have more stocks of firewood, she could also cater to other neighboring villages, thereby increasing her income. Therefore, she is requesting KIVA loan assistance of PHP 10,000.00 to increase her working capital.

loans.use: Additional working capital

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A., 30,is married and has three children, one son and two daughters.  Her sons attend junior high primary schools.  She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy fishing/commercial town called Mankessim, near Cape Coast in the Central region of Ghana.  She works to support her husband financially to provide for the family.  Her husband runs a drug store.  Elizabeth is a food vendor. She sells porridge.  Elizabeth prepares it in her house and sells by the road side.  She procures bags of maize and beans from the local market.  She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and beans in bulk.  Elizabeth is hopeful to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: Procure bags of maize and beans.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel S. is 46 years old. He is married and has six children: three daughters and three sons. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Samuel says his children are currently in junior high and primary school. His wife is a farmer.

Samuel is a commercial driver. He drives a taxi cab. He conveys goods and people to and from his community and other nearby communities. He works from morning to evening. He says his car, which is his only source of income, is virtually broken down and so he wants a loan to have it repaired and maintained. Samuel has been driving more than 15 years. Samuel is hoping to maintain the car and improve his standard of living. He is also hoping to give his children a sound education.

loans.use: To repair vehicle

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is from the village of Mabini, Baliangao Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns & operates a business; her main source of income comes from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 1 year.

In 2004, Susan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and improve her business.  Susan repaid a previous loan of 10,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 22-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon. Mohamad has been working as a refrigerator and washing machine repairman for two years. Mohamad has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase a pickup truck for his work. This is the first time that Mohamad has requested a loan.

Mohamad is special in his work because he is efficient, as well as punctual. His clients can be anybody. When Mohamad first started his business, he had difficulty networking. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase a pickup truck

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Azangarinas Valientes”  que esta ubicado en el del distrito de Azangaro, provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 51 años de edad, de estado civil casada, es madre de 08 hijos (6 a su cargo) y tiene estudios primaria incompleta (3ro grado).  Dinora Elena Castillo Vivar. Vive en el Barrio Revolución Jr. América Nueva.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace mas de 1 ano, su préstamo inicial de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, con el cual compró insumos para su negocio de venta de jugos. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 1000.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de papayas, naranja, plátano, azúcar, leche, para la preparación de jugos.  Ella también vende verduras en las ferias.

Su deseo es hacer crecer más su negocio.

A ella le gusta la forma de los préstamos y sus facilidades de pago.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana is a member of the Community Bank "Azangarinas Valientes" which is located in the district of Azangaro, Azangaro Province, Puno state. She is 51 years old, married and the mother of 8 children, 6 of which still depend on her. She did not finish elementary school (3rd grade)

She has worked with Manuela Ramos institution for more than 1 year, her first loan was $500.00 nuevos soles, which was invested in the purchase of ingredients to make juice.

She is asking for a loan of $350 for the purchase of papayas, oranges, bananas, sugar and milk, for the preparation of juices. She also sells vegetables at her booth. Her desire is to grow her business. She likes the way how the loans work.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rita

texts.es:
La señora Rita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Medalla de oro II”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Puno, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 31 años de edad, estado civil conviviente, es madre de 02 hijos y tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en la Urb. Villa Florida.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 08 años, inició en otro Banco Comunal, descansó 3 años y en el actual esta 2 años como socia.  Su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles,  dinero que utilizó para implementar el taller de soldadura de su esposo ya que los dos trabajan. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de soldaduras para el taller.  Lo dirigen sus empleados, ya que los dos trabajan en la Universidad Nacional del Altiplano.
La señora Rita también tiene un kiosco de venta de repuestos que abre solo en vacaciones y a veces los domingos.

Su deseo es construir su casa ya que cuenta con terreno propio y luego darles una profesión a sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las reuniones dice que es una forma de relajarse ya que comparte sus experiencias diarias.
texts.en:
Rita belongs to the Medalla de Oro II Communal Bank which is located in the Villa Florida neighborhood, of the Puno District, in the Puno Province. She is 31 years old, a common-law wife, mother of two children and has completed secondary studies. Rita has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for eight years but started at a different Communal Bank and then took 3 years off. She is currently a member of two years. Her initial loan was for 300 nuevos soles, money that she used to set up her husband's welding workshop since they both work. Now she needs a loan of 500 nuevos soles for purchasing solder for the workshop. Rita also has a kiosk where she sells spare parts which she only opens during vacations or sometimes on Sundays. Her hope is to build her own house since she has her own land, and to later provide her children with careers. Rita likes meetings because she says that it's a way to relax since she gets to share her daily experiences.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Shimmin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For purchasing solder

loans.name: Fidela

texts.en:
Fidela A. is a 63-year-old widow from Mulawin, Maricaban, Pasay City. She has five dependents with the eldest already making a living and helping her augment their basic daily needs.

Fidela runs a community pharmacy selling generic medicines at affordable prices. She started this business last year. Fidela makes a monthly profit of more than P7,000. She laments, however, that come rainy season, sales decrease as she has to close her store because of the perennial flooding in the city and the flood waters that run through her pharmacy.

Since 2001, she has been an active member of Kiva partner the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and has benefited from its many programs and services empowering women in poor communities.

Fidela is asking for a loan of P10,000 in order to buy more medicine to sell at her pharmacy. She is dependent on income from the business to buy medication for one of her children who has epilepsy. She would also like to refurbish her pharmacy to address the perennial flood problem that adversely affects her business.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase medicine to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda T. is from the village of Talairon, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 62 years old. Erlinda is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business selling dried fish to local community members. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP so that she can purchase additional dried fish to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.  It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 41 years old she is divorced and mother of two children. Currently they are all in school. She sells porridge at her neighborhood. Porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed popularly as breakfast by almost all Ghanaians. Her porridge is prepared from milled maize or millet grains, boiled and taken with sugar, milk and bread or taking with what we called Kose. Kose is prepared from milled beans and it is fried with cooking oil so in just about 20minutes it is ready to be served with the porridge. With large customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of millet, beans, sugar and milk to increase production. She hopes to raise good income to support her kids in school and make business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, milk etc.

loans.name: Las Mañanitas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las mañanitas está integrado por  Joana L., Gloria G., Darling de los Ángeles L. y Walkiria F.. La coordinadora del grupo es Yoana L. quien comenzó hace cinco años con un capital de 2,500 córdobas los cuales invirtió en la compra de ropa y jabones que vende en el mercado de Masaya. Luego de esto solicito un préstamo en Adim quien le proporciono estabilidad y crecimiento.

Las otras integrantes son Gloria G., tiene tres años de vender zapatos y chinelas en el mercado de Masaya, Darling L. vende zapatos y sandalias y Walkiria F. comercializa juguetes y adornos. El mayor sueño de ellas es aumentar sus negocios y prosperar para ello requieren de invertir en materia prima para sus negocios.
texts.en:
Joana L., Gloria G., Darling de los Ángeles L., and Walkiria F. make up the Las Mañanitas Group. Joana L. is the coordinator of the group. She started five years ago with 2,500 córdobas, and she bought clothes and soaps to sell in the Masaya market. After that, she asked for a loan from Adim, which gave her stability and growth. The other members are: Gloria G. has been selling shoes and slippers in the Masaya market for three years. Darling L. sells shoes and sandals. Walkiria F. sells toys and decorations. Their biggest dream is to expand their businesses and prosper. To do so they need to invest in raw material for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes, soaps, shoes, and toys

loans.name: Sahalatu

texts.en: Sahalatu is 35 years old and is a mother of four children. Three are in school and her youngest is still breastfeeding. To support her household, she has been selling cereals like beans, maize, millet, rice and groundnuts in the community market to her loyal customers. She says selling these products is very lucrative. She has been in business for the last five years now and has gained lots of business experience. She takes delivery of stock from the farming communities in the northern part of Ghana and from some in Burkina Faso. She is requesting the loan to increase her stock as we approach the Christmas festivities. She believes this would enable her make a good income to support her family, especially for their education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like groundnut, rice, maize, millet and beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To diversify her milk business.

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: H. Célestine est née en 1969 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Célestine est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C’est une divorcée, vivant seule avec ses enfants au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestine réside dans ce quartier depuis 10 ans. C’est Célestine qui assure seule les charges de la famille. Célestine n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a 8 ans déjà que Célestine mène comme activité, la vente de pâtés (faits à base de farine de blé). Célestine vend également de l’huile végétale ainsi que des produits vivriers (maïs, haricot) à son domicile et par le système de distribution.
