C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Célestine fait ses achats. Célestine a obtenu deux fois déjà de crédits à ALIDé et les a bien remboursés. Célestine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d’agrandir davantage son activité et d’attirer plus la clientèle.
texts.en:
H. Célestine was born in 1969 in Allada, in Atlantique county, Benin. She is the mother of four children who are all in school. She is divorced and living alone with her children in the Cadjèhoun district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been residing in this district for ten years. She alone ensures that family needs are met. Célestine did not go to school. For eight years already, she has been running a business selling pâtés (made with wheat flour). She also sells vegetable oil, as well as staple foods (corn, beans) out of her home and by the distribution system. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she makes her purchases. She twice had an ALIDé loan and has repaid them. She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé to expand her business further and to attract more customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wheat flour, corn, and beans

loans.name: Remequita

texts.en:
Remequita S. is from the city of Jungle Town, San Vicente Urdaneta. She is 53 years old. Remequita is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Remequita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Remequita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Remequita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remequita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Remequita is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Remequita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly comprised of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Jungle Town San Vicente, Urdaneta City

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P. has a farm. She grows rice to provide her family with an adequate supply of food and clothing and take care of their other basic needs. She has one child who is 14 years old now. Currently, her child is studying in high school. Emma dreams of saving enough money to pay for her child's college tuition and books in the future.

Now, she is asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will be truly helpful for buying farm supplies to grow her crops.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.es:
Teofilo A. C., tiene la edad de 77 años, está en unión libre, y tiene un hijo que es su mayor prioridad. El hijo tiene 36 años. El crédito lo quiere para asistir una plantación de café, de plátano y pasto. Además, desea comprar el fertilizante para darle el adecuado mantenimiento a los cultivos, esto le va a permitir tener una mayor producción y así tener mayores ingresos económicos. Don Teofilo también se dedica al cultivo de árboles frutales y pasto.Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le dieron.El espera en un futuro brindarle a su hijo y a toda su familia una mejor calidad de vida.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Teofilo A. C. is 77 years old, in a common law marriage, and has one son who is his biggest priority. His son is 36 years old. The loan he is requesting is to help him plant coffee, bananas, and grass. Also, he would like to buy fertilizer to better maintain his crops and produce a bigger harvest in order to improve his income. Teofilo also grows fruit trees and grass. This is his first loan from FUDECOSUR and he is very pleased with what they have provided him. He hopes to provide a better life and better standard of living for his son and his family. About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farm maintenance

loans.name: Elena Tag-Ulo Group

texts.en:
Elena T. is from the village of Colambutan Settlement, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old. Elena is the group leader for a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elena is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Elena raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 36 years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Elena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young plants to raise. Elena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Elena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Gertrudiz Maribel

texts.es:
La señora Gertrudiz Maribel forma parte del Banco Comunal Aníbal San Andrés esta conformado por 19 prestataria las reuniones son en el Cantón Montecristi, este lugar es reconocido por su artesanía y por sus atractivos turísticos como sus hermosas playas en el provincia de Manabí.

Gertrudiz Maribel comparte el negocio con su esposo ellos se dedican a la compra y venta de pescado, lo compran en la playa de Manta a la madrugada que llegan los pescadores al puerto en sus lanchas, adquieren el pescado por gavetas ya fileteado listo para preparase o para ser enviado a Quito al mercado San Roque o al mercado Mayorista donde tienen sus clientes fijos, otra parte del pescado lo vende en su casa a su vecinos del sector.

Nuestra socia con este nuevo préstamo comprará gavetas  y más pescado para abstecer a sus clientes siempre e incrementar su negocio y buscar nuevos clientes, así como para aumentar sus ganacias
texts.en:
Mrs Gertrudiz Maribel is a member of the communal bank Anibal San Andrés. The meetings have 19 lending groups in the Montecristi Canton, a place known for its handicrafts and for its tourist attractions, such as the beautiful beaches in the Manabí province. Gertrudiz Maribel has the business with her husband. Together they work buying and selling fish They buy the fish on the Manta beach at dawn when the fishermen come in in their boats. They collect the filleted fish in containers and either have it ready to cook, or to send to Quito for the San Roque market or for the wholesale market. There they have their regular customers. They also sell the fish to their neighbors from their home. Our member will use the loan to buy containers, and more fish to be able to supply her customers all the time and to increase her business, and to look for new customers. This way she can have more profit.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers and more fish

loans.name: Nazirjon

texts.en: Nazirjon S. is a hard-working man who goes to cultivate his fields every morning with great care. Along with that, he tends to his calves, taking them to feed in the mornings. His work demonstrates his dedication to his cows, since one way or another they help solve his household expenses. Early in the morning, his wife milks them and sells the milk at nearby places. Most recently, Nazirjon wants to invest in purchasing another cow so that his wife can take more milk to the cities to sell, helping his business to continue growing economically. He is requesting a loan of 7,500 Somoni for this purpose. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle for developing business

loans.name: Zacheous

texts.en:
Zacheous is 35 years and he lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is married with two children who both attend school. His wife also works to support their home.
Zacheous is a farmer and also a pastor. He has a very large farm where he plants cassava. He has been in this business for 17 years. He hopes to expand his farming business, and is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cassava stem to plant. He sends thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava stem to plant

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es: El Sr. Julio Cesar Ramírez A. Trabaja como jardinero en un hotel de playa es padre de un hijo el diario se presenta a su centro de trabajo para realizar las actividades que le asignen algunas veces tiene que hacer turnos de noche para regar las áreas verdes del hotel. El crédito lo solicito para mejoras en su vivienda  y pago de la mano de obra .
texts.en:
El Sr. Julio Cesar Ramírez A. Trabaja como jardinero en un hotel de playa es padre de un hijo el diario se presenta a su centro de trabajo para realizar las actividades que le asignen algunas veces tiene que hacer turnos de noche para regar las áreas verdes del hotel. El crédito lo solicito para mejoras en su vivienda y pago de la mano de obra .

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construcción de su vivienda, Compra de cemento, arena, cerámica, bonder, encalichador, bloques, y mano de obra.

loans.name: Dammika

texts.en:
Dammika  is a 33-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa, Galle with four children (ages sixteen to five) and her husband. All her children are still studying. She works hard, together with her husband, to uplift their lives. Dammika's husband has a carpentry business for which they are seeking a loan to expand their venture. They build chairs, tables, cupboards, beds and other items.

She has asked for a loan of 55,000 rupees (LKR) from BRAC in order to purchase some wood. They have been in this business for ten years and they want to buy new machines for carpentry eventually. She hopes to open a new carpentry shop in the near future as well. This will be Dammika's third loan.  She paid her first and second loans off without any problems.  

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy  wood for carpentry

loans.name: Frishta Sardar Group

texts.en: Belqis is daughter of S. Q., 52 years old and the leader of Frishta Sardar group. She is married and the mother of eight children. She lives in district 7th of Kabul, Afghanistan. Her husband has a general store and all the family members benefit from his income. She wants to take a loan for her husband's store. Her husband wants to expand his business and to attract more clients, so she has requested a loan for her husband. Now both are happy that they have the chance to progress as soon as possible.

loans.use: To expand his business and to attract more clients

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Este banco comunal se denomina “RICCHARY RUNA”; se reúnen cada mes por la tarde en el distrito de Huanchac, de la provincia de Cusco y departamento Cusco.

Nuestro socio es él  Sr. Daniel; Es viudo y tiene 60 años de edad, tiene 5 hijos ya todos independientes,  el socio es natural de Cusco y estudios solo secundaria completa, el por motivos económicos no pudo estudiar la superior, Nuestro socio es conductor y tiene su propio carro y presta servicio de turismo y taxi. Nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para mejorar su casa.

El socio agradece el préstamo y valorando el mismo, se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “RICCHARY RUNA”; they meet every month in the afternoon in the Huanchac district, which is in the Cusco province and department. This member is Daniel. He is a widower who is 60 years old. He has 5 children who are now all independent. He is a native of Cusco and completed only his secondary education; for economic reasons he could not study at a higher level. He is a driver, and he has his own car with which he provides taxi and tourism services. He is requesting a loan to improve his house. Daniel is grateful for this loan and values it highly. He is committed to making his payments according to the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to make improvements to his house

loans.name: Jose Vicente

texts.es:
José de 30 años, vive en el Fortín de Guayaquil (perímetro periurbano con restos de una ecología en disolución). El tiene una tienda de vegetales y frutas en su casa.  

Con esfuerzo y dedicación el pudo construir una parte de su casa y convertirla en una pequeña tienda. Trabaja desde las 05h00am hasta las 23h00pm. Para tener mas oportunidad de incrementar su negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo arroz, azúcar y aceite y así surtir mas su tienda. 

En el futuro quiere ser comerciante mayoristas de vegetales y frutas, también poder construir su casa mas grande.
texts.en:
José is 30 years old and lives in Fortín de Guayaqui (a periurban zone with the remains of a disintegrating ecosystem). He has a fruit and vegetable shop in his house. With hard work and dedication he was able to built his house and converted part of it into a small shop. He works from 5am til 11pm at night. To create better opportunities to grow his business he wants to buy rice, sugar and oil with this loan to stock his shop better. In the future José wants to be a wholesaler of fruit and vegetables, and build a bigger house.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar and oil

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen C. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 33 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Lower Tambo, Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. Helen has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda L. is from Barangay Nagcuartelan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old and is married with four adult children. Merlinda owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling cosmetics and personal products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Merlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Gulasal

texts.en:
Gulasal I. llives in Kadamjai, a nice town is the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 42 and is married. She has three sons: her oldest son studies at university and the others are at school. 

Gulasal owns a shop where she sells convenience goods. Her husband went to work in Russia, so she controls all the family business by herself. Gulasal opened her shop four years ago with the initial investment of 30,000 soms and now she makes 24,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to repair her house and save money to pay for her son’s education at university. 

With this loan she wants to purchase 100kg of sugar, 30-40 packs of various drinks, vegetables, oil and other goods. In the future she plans to expand her business and purchase a vehicle to decrease her transportation costs.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase stock

loans.name: Anisa

texts.en:
Anisa K. is a resident of Karabalta, a small city near Bishkek. She is 59 and married with a son and a daughter, both of them married. Twenty years ago with the initial investment of 1000 soms Anisa started to sell cosmetics in the market. In this way she makes 35000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a house and then a container. Anisa applies for the loan because she needs money to purchase more cosmetics to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to save money and provide a good education to her grandchildren.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo P. is from the village of Sinait. He is 61 years old. Rodolfo is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Rodolfo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 36 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rodolfo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Luz es conviviente, tiene 2 hijos que estudian, Luz junto a su esposo tienen una tienda en local alquilado en donde brinda servicios de fotocopiado de planos, y hace 4 meses inicio con el revelado de fotos, negocio que esta mejorando.
Luz es socia del Banco Comunal Granito de Mostaza y solicita un crédito de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de monitores para las computadoras, papel y tinta.
Los sueños de Luz son construir su casa de material noble, actualmente es de material rustico y tener una sucursal.
texts.en:
Luz lives with her life partner and their two children who are in school. Luz and her husband have a store in a rented locale where they offer blueprint photocopying services. Four months ago she added photo developing, a business that is improving. Luz is a member of the “Granito de Mostaza” (Little Mustard Seed) communal bank and is asking for a 3000 sol loan to invest in computer monitors, paper and ink. Luz’s dreams are to build her house with substantial materials; it’s currently built with flimsy materials. She’d also like to open a second branch of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy computer monitors, paper and ink.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn P. is from the village of Calamagui. She is 34 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,800 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jocelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Urumuri A Group

texts.en: Urumuri, which is the name of this loan group, means Light in the Kinyarwanda language. Each of this group's members makes a living selling various items locally. Peteronille, the group leader, is 35 years old, married and has four children who are between the ages of five and 11. All of her children are in school. Her husband works as a farmer. Peteronille runs a shop where she sells household and food items such as sugar, soaps, rice, lotions and soda. She has had this business for 20 years and will use her portion of this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.  She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to pay her children's school fees. She has succeeded in business because she knows her customers well. In the future, she hopes to buy a house where she can also run her business. In the photo, we see Peteronille seated in the second row holding up her Urwego Opportunity Bank Passbook.

loans.use: To buy more food and household goods to sell to her customers

loans.name: Cecibel

texts.es:
Cecibel, tiene 45 años de edad, reside en El Divisadero, departamento de Morazán, se dedica a la venta de comida, antojitos (comida rápida) y bisutería; vive con su esposo y su hijo Juan Antonio, su negocio es variado ya que ofrece almuerzos, antojitos como enchiladas, yuca frita, panes con pollo y también vende bisutería (collares y pulseras de piedras).
Ella pretende progresar con el negocio y para realizarlo solicita un préstamo para tener el dinero necesario para comprar los materiales para fabricar bisutería y además comprar productos para preparar las comidas como pollo, maíz, condimentos; de esta manera tendrá un buen inventario para dar salida a las demandas de los clientes.
El sueño de ella es construir algún día su propia casa para vivir cómodamente con su familia.
texts.en:
Cecibel is 45 years old.  She lives in El Divisadero, in Morazán department.  She works selling food, 'antojitos' (fast food) and imitation jewelry.  She lives with her husband and her son Juan Antonio.  Her business is varied since she offers lunches, fast food such as enchiladas, fried yucca, 'panes con pollo' (traditional Salvadorean chicken sandwich with tomato-based sauce), and also sells imitation jewelry (stone necklaces and bracelets).

She plans to make progress in her business and for this reason she is requesting a loan so that she has the necessary money to buy materials for making jewelry and also products for preparing meals such as chicken, corn and condiments.  In this way she will have a good inventory with which she can fulfil her customers' demands.

Her dream is to some day build her own house so that she can live comfortably with her family.

loans.use: To buy chicken, corn and condiments, and materials for making jewelry

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Lidia vive en casa de sus padres en la zona Llojeta, de la ciudad de La Paz, con su madre y su hermana de 15 años; es soltera y trabaja como educadora de nivel primario en un centro de ayuda social de su zona, con los ingresos que obtiene se mantiene. Es la primera vez que presenta una solicitud de créditos. El dinero será utilizado para demoler una antigua habitación hecha de adobe, que se encuentra fuera de la línea municipal, y construir una nueva habitación de ladrillo en la casa de sus padres.

Por su estudio socio económico califica para obtener un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Lidia lives with her mother and 15 year old sister, parents in the Llojeta zone of La Paz.  She’s single, works as a teacher in a social assistance center in her zone, and supports herself with this income.

This is her first loan request and she will use the money to raze an old adobe house outside the city limits and build a new brick home.  Her socioeconomic situation qualifies her for this loan.

loans.use: Build a house

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
Juan Antonio Pérez Madrigal, tiene la edad de 42 años, está en unión Libre y tiene 2 hijos que es su mayor prioridad. El quiere comprar los alimentos para el mantenimiento de unos animales de cría y mantenerlos un tiempo más, mientras el precio de la venta del ganado suba un poco más. El siempre se ha dedicado a  esta actividad y le ido muy bien, por lo cual él quiere aguantar la venta de sus animales pues actualmente el precio del ganado esta muy mal pagado. También él piensa en el futuro de sus hijos y pretende generar un poquito más de ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida Familiar.
Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. El  no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Juan Antonio Pérez Madrigal is 42 years old and lives with his common-law partner.  He has 2 children that are his main priority.  He wants to buy feed for the animals that he raises.  He would like to keep them a bit longer while cattle prices increase a little more because currently, livestock prices are very low.  He has always done this for a living and it has gone well for him.   He is also thinking of his children's future and wants to generate a bit more income to provide a better quality of life for his family. 

This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR.  He hasn't had any previous loans with state banks, but FUDECOSUR has provided him with a loan with easy terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his livestock

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa tiene 67 años D. edad, es viuda y resiD. junto a uno D. sus hijos y a una cuñada en el distrito D. Jayanca, una zona agrícola que se encuentra situada en la provincia D. Lambayeque, a más D. una hora D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica desD. hace más D. veinte años a la venta D. artículos para celebración D. fiestas infantiles (piñatería) para lo cual cuenta con un establecimiento instalado en su domicilio. Adicionalmente alquila sillas y toldos para dichas actividades. Este negocio le permite ayudar al sostenimiento económico D. su familia.

Teresa desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más mercadería, con esta inversión ella espera satisfacer la demanda con la que cuenta y seguir progresando. Para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad D. solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 2000 nuevos soles.
texts.en: Teresa is 67 years old, widowed, and lives with her children and a sister-in-law in Jayanca district, an agricultura zone located in Lambayeque province, more than an hour from the city of Chiclayo. She has been selling supplies for children's parties (piñatería) for over 20 years. Her business is set up in her house. She also rents chairs and tents for parties. This business allows her to help meet her family's economic needs. Teresa would like to expand her business by acquiring more merchandise. She hopes that, with this investment, she will be able to meet her customers' demand, which has consistently been increasing. In order to achieve her goal, she decided to request a loan of 2,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to expand her business with more merchandise

loans.name: Carmelita Enomar Group

texts.en:
Carmelita E. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Carmelita is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of the other group member, if the other one is delinquent or defaults.

Carmelita is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.


In 2009, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Carmelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fertilizer

loans.name: Dok

texts.en: Dok C., 51, is married and resides with her family in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. C. sells food, earning an income of USD 20 per day. Her husband sells cows for an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 100 on food and USD 20 on the other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a new motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Delfin

texts.en:
Delfin M. lives Pingol Ozamiz City. He is 55 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For more than a year, he has made a living by providing transportation services, and earns about 10,000 PHP a month from his work.

Earlier this year, Delfin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for this loan for 15,000 PHP to repair his vehicle so he can provide his customers with better service. He plans to use the additional revenue made possible by his repaired vehicle to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and women and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle so he can provide better service

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar G. is from the town of Surallah. He is 48 years old. Oscar is married and has a 7-year-old child. To make a living, Oscar owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Oscar also owns a cow he uses for plowing.

Oscar joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oscar has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Oscar is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, age 21, is currently in the business of selling tea. She and her busband, who is smployed as a policeman, have one small child. Their child is as yet too young to attend school.

Monica is requesting a loan in order to stock more tea to sell. In the future, she hopes to expand her business with the extra profits expected from the loan.

loans.use: to stock more tea to offer for sale

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia T. is from the village of Galingon, Tamilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 32 years old. Virginia is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Virginia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina M. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Saturnina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Saturnina owns & operates a fish vending business in her local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Saturnina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC.  

Saturnina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this investment to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Hiedeliza

texts.en:
Hiedeliza S. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 50 years old, married, and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Hiedeliza owns & operates a business providing motorela or habal-habal transport services to local community members. Hiedeliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Hiedeliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hiedeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase tools needed to provide service. 

Hiedeliza is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to purchase additional tools & supplies needed for the maintenance of her business. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: José, de 42 años, es un buen padre de familia; hace 20 años que convive con Placida, con quien tiene 4 hijos que son su motivación diaria, y los que cuida en su casa propia, ubicada en el caserío de Santo Domingo. Papa, arveja, maíz, habas y diversas verduras, es lo que a diario cultiva desde hace 20 años, junto a su cónyuge y la compañía de sus hijos, puede mantener siempre limpios sus terrenos. Lo que más le gusta es sembrar exactamente en la temporada de siembra, no antes ni después, de otro modo le resulta difícil retirar la mala hierba de las chacras, porque al regar sus tierras crece junto a los cultivos. Para él, el oficio de la agricultura es bastante rentable porque le permitió adquirir sus bienes como su casa, sus terrenos agrícolas y demás enseres, por eso no piensa dejar de lado el labrado de la tierra. Asimismo menciona que se dedica a la compra y venta de piña; viajando a la ciudad de Santa Ana, donde acopia este producto para después llevarlo a la capital del país, ganando un nuevo sol por cada cajón, según menciona llega a vender de 600 a 700 cajones. Ahora para poder mejorar su economía, en vista de que sus hijos están creciendo, desea instalar un negocio de tienda de comestibles en su casa, aprovechando que no hay una bodega en su sector. Él pertenece al banco comunal “Santo domingo de Tapo”, y este es el segundo crédito con MFP, donde agradece a los integrantes de su banco comunal, quienes le recomiendan como una persona pagadora, se compromete a no defraudarlos, por lo que pagará sus cuotas de manera puntual. José, invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de varias cosechas de piña; invirtiendo un promedio de S/. 800 soles semanales.
texts.en: Jose, 42, is a responsible man. He has been partnered with Placida for 20 years and they have 4 children who they have raised in a house that they own near Santo Domingo. Jose has operated a farming business for 20 years. He grows potatoes, peas, maize, beans and a variety of vegatables, all of which he carefully tends with help from his family. He is very careful to plant his crops at exactly the right time, neither too early nor too late, because otherwise it becomes difficult to get rid of the weeds that grow along with the crop.  He says that the farm is profitable and earns enough to support his family, so he has no plans to leave it.  However, he does have another source of income, buying and selling pineapples.  He travels to the city of Santa Ana where he stocks up on pineapples and then carries the merchandise to the capital for sale.  He earns one Peruvian sol for each of the 600 or 700 boxes that he sells.  Now he's looking at another business.  He wants to set up a store in his house where he can sell everyday commodities.  There aren't any similar shops in his community so he thinks it will be a good business.  Jose belongs to the Santo Domingo de Tapo community bank and this is his second MFP loan.  His fellow members are confident that he will repay the loan on time.  Jose will use the loan for his pineapple business.  He expects to spend S/.800 soles per week.

loans.use: Comprar cajas de piña.

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda is 31 years old and married with five school-aged children. She is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. To make a living, Glenda owns and operates a specialized retail store. Her main source of income comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Glenda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

Glenda joined HSPFI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional canned goods and junk food. This is the first loan taken out by Glenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve and expand her business.


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods and junk food to sell

loans.name: Aizada's Group

texts.en:
Aizada is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married to a builder. Together they bring up two sons and two daughters. The sons and the older daughter study at school, the second daughter is preschool age (under seven). In order to contribute additional money to family budget and meet the daily needs Aizada breeds livestock and then resells it at a higher price in the market. She started this activity two years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms and now she earns 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future Aizada wishes to build a new house and improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock
